citation.article-title: Physiology, phylogenetic relationships, and ecology of filamentous sulfate-reducing bacteria (genus Desulfonema)

p.s: Description of Desulfonema ishimotoi sp. nov.
Desulfonema ishimotoi (i.shi.mo'to.i M.L.gen.n., of Ishimoto; named after Makoto Ishimoto, a Japanese biochemist and microbiologist)
The genus Desulfonema has been described elsewhere (Widdel 1989).
Multicellular gliding filaments, 2.3–3 μm in diameter and 0.05–1 μm in length; individual cells are 2–5 μm long.
Sulfate serves as electron acceptor and is reduced to sulfide.

Hydrogen plus carbon dioxide, formate, acetate, propionate, higher fatty acids up to 14 carbon atoms, lactate, pyruvate, succinate, fumarate, ethanol, 1-propanol, or 1-butanol may serve as electron donors and carbon sources.
Growth on hydrogen plus carbon dioxide or formate does not require additional carbon sources, but is stimulated by low concentrations (1 mM) of acetate.
Malate, benzoate, and glucose are not utilized.
The temperature optimum for growth is 30 °C.
The type strain requires a saline medium with 20 g NaCl, 3.0 g MgCl2·6H2O, and 0.2 g CaCl2·2H2O per liter.
The sulfite reductase desulfoviridin is present.
Presence of carbon monoxide dehydrogenase and formate dehydrogenase indicates oxidation of acetyl-coenzyme A via the C1-pathway (carbon monoxide dehydrogenase pathway, reverse Wood pathway).
The G+C content of the DNA is 54.7–55 mol%.
Strains have been isolated from anoxic marine mud rich in organic substances.
